question.qText: Which of the following is best described as a single displacement reaction?

aBtn.aText:
AgNO3 (aq) + KOH (aq) →
KNO3 (aq) + AgOH (s)

P<font face='SubScript'>4</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 5O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> (<font face="c-Italic">g</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 2P<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O<font face='SubScript'>5</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>)

NH4Cl (aq) + LiOH (aq) →
LiCl (aq) + H2O (l) + NH3 (g)

2Cu (s) + PtCl4 (aq) →
2CuCl2 (aq) + Pt (s)

question.qText: Which of the following combines a double displacement reaction with a decomposition reaction?

aBtn.aText:
AgNO3 (aq) + KOH (aq) →
KNO3 (aq) + AgOH (s)

P<font face='SubScript'>4</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 5O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> (<font face="c-Italic">g</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 2P<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O<font face='SubScript'>5</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>)

NH4Cl (aq) + LiOH (aq) →
LiCl (aq) + H2O (l) + NH3 (g)

2Cu (s) + PtCl4 (aq) →
2CuCl2 (aq) + Pt (s)

question.qText: Which of the following is a reaction that can be classified as both a synthesis and a combustion reaction?

aBtn.aText:
AgNO3 (aq) + KOH (aq) →
KNO3 (aq) + AgOH (s)

P<font face='SubScript'>4</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 5O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> (<font face="c-Italic">g</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 2P<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O<font face='SubScript'>5</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>)

NH4Cl (aq) + LiOH (aq) →
LiCl (aq) + H2O (l) + NH3 (g)

2Cu (s) + PtCl4 (aq) →
2CuCl2 (aq) + Pt (s)

question.qText: Which of the following is a double displacement reaction that has the formation of a precipitate as its driving force?

aBtn.aText:
AgNO3 (aq) + KOH (aq) →
KNO3 (aq) + AgOH (s)

P<font face='SubScript'>4</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 5O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> (<font face="c-Italic">g</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 2P<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O<font face='SubScript'>5</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>)

NH4Cl (aq) + LiOH (aq) →
LiCl (aq) + H2O (l) + NH3 (g)

2Cu (s) + PtCl4 (aq) →
2CuCl2 (aq) + Pt (s)

question.qText: Which of these reactions is also classified as a redox reaction? Click VIEW to see the reactions.

aBtn.aText: B only
C only
A and C
B and D

question.qText: Which of the following best represents the net ionic equation for the reaction of magnesium metal with nitric acid?

aBtn.aText:
Mg (s) + 2HNO3 (aq) →
H2 (g) + Mg(NO3)2 (aq)

Mg (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 2H<font face='SuperScript'>+</font> (<font face="c-Italic">aq</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> H<font face='SubScript'>2</font> (<font face="c-Italic">g</font>) + Mg<font face='SuperScript'>2+</font> (<font face="c-Italic">aq</font>)

Mg (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 2H<font face='SuperScript'>+</font> (<font face="c-Italic">aq</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> MgH<font face='SubScript'>2</font> (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>)

Mg (<font face="c-Italic">s</font>) + 2NO<font face='chemNums''SubScript'>3</font><font face=='chemNums''SuperScript'>−</font> (<font face="c-Italic">aq</font>) <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> Mg(NO<font face='SubScript'>3</font>)<font face='SubScript'>2</font>(<font face="c-Italic">aq</font>)

question.qText: Which of the following describes a key way in which decomposition and synthesis differ?

aBtn.aText: Synthesis reactions are always redox reactions.
Synthesis reactions are typically endothermic and require energy.
Decomposition typically requires the input of energy to occur.
Decomposition reactions never produce pure elements.

question.qText: Which of the following is a key difference between single displacement and double displacement reactions?

aBtn.aText: Only single displacement reactions have two reactants.
Only single displacement reactions are also classified as redox reactions.
Only double displacement reactions form solids.
Only double displacement reactions can involve acid as a reactant.

question.qText: Which of these is the correct order for the activity of the metals involved, from most active to least active? Click VIEW to see the reactions.

aBtn.aText: Ba , Mg, Cd, Sn
Mn, Ba, Cd, Sn
Sn, Cd, Mg, Mn
Mg, Sn, Cd, Ba

question.qText: Which of the following reactions best represent the balanced reaction for the complete combustion of the pentane, C<font face='SubScript'>5</font>H<font face='SubScript'>12</font>?

aBtn.aText: C<font face='SubScript'>5</font>H<font face='SubScript'>12</font> + 5O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 5CO<font face='SubScript'>2</font> + 6H<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O
C<font face='SubScript'>5</font>H<font face='SubScript'>12</font> + 11O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 5CO + 6H<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O

C<font face='SubScript'>5</font>H<font face='SubScript'>12</font> + 8O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 5CO<font face='SubScript'>2</font> + 6H<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O
2C<font face='SubScript'>5</font>H<font face='SubScript'>12</font> + 17O<font face='SubScript'>2</font> <font face='CambriaMath'>→</font> 10CO + 12H<font face='SubScript'>2</font>O
